title: FedBench: A Benchmark Suite for Federated Semantic Data Query Processing
segmentation: I'm talking today about Fat Bench or benchmark.
We proposed for Federated Data Processing and this is joint work from Peter, has Andrea SWAT and me from fluid operations.

All of Garlitz from West Institute and Grendel at which antenna transform KIT and this work was done as part of the call Up Cloud project and one of the goals there was to develop a platform where we can share data across enterprises.
In a Federated way and there we first step was to evaluate existing approaches in the context of link data for Federation and also develop new solutions.
So what are the possibilities when evaluating linked data?
Basically, there are two valid approaches.
The first one is a data warehousing approach where we have a central repository.
We have our RDF datasets and we load these datasets into a central repository and when asking queries we ask these queries directly against the repository and the repository then gives the queries.
Outback.

In different we have these Federated query approaches where instead of working on a single repository we are asking queries against the Federation layer and this Federation layer is responsible for delegating queries, sub queries to independent Federation members and then aggregating the results that it gets back from these Federation members to compose the final query output.
And in the context of linked data, we might have quite a heterogeneous settings here, so we may have different types of federations members.

We may have local, native, repository's that are contributing to the results, or me, or we may want to have sparkle endpoints which we can query and get partial query results from or also linked data that is hidden behind HTTP interfaces where we simply send HTTP requests to resolve your eyes and get information about.
Is your eyes back to answer queries in maybe an iterative?
Fashion, so maybe a couple of more comparison between this centralized and Federated approach in this centralized approach.
What we typically do is we periodically crawl and gather the relevant data, so whenever the original sources are updated, we have to get these updates into our central repository.
And here we have of course a benefit when we're using a Federated setting, because we can use the original data sources as is, and whenever these original sources are.
Updated our queries that we asked automatically reflect the actual query results.
One benefit we have in the centralized approach is that typically we have.

Typically we have a local repository where we can guarantee high reliability and we have a high controllability and this is a little bit more problematic in the Federated setting where often we use third party and points to ask queries.
So we have in the general Case No control over these Federation members.

On the other hand, a drawback of the centralized approach is that it is quite inflexible in terms of datasets, which means when I want to use new datasets, what I have to do is I have to locate the data I have to load the data into the repository, which may take a couple of hours so I will lose some time and need some preparation to start using new data sources, whereas in the Federated approach what I can do I simply tell my Federation layer my sparkle endpoint.
Is at at this address and I can immediately start querying this endpoint.
And finally, from a query optimization approach, when we have a centralized approach, it is arguably a little bit easier to deal with query optimization because we often have full control.

We have elaborate statistics, we can calculate statistics on this local repository, but in a Federated setting where we do not have full control, we may have only partial knowledge about the data that is inside these endpoints about the distribution of data about predicates, which makes it.
Harder to optimize query.

On the other hand, we also gain optimization opportunities by parallelizing queries or subqueries or delegating requests to the endpoints that do some work for is for us, evaluate partial queries and give us already partial results back, which we then can use in the Federation layer.
So the takeaway here is that both approaches may have practical use cases, and the point is that they have radically different requirements, challenges, and characteristics to be addressed.
So coming back to the issue of benchmarking now for this centralized approach, variety of benchmarks have been proposed in previous work like the Boleyns Parker Benchmark.
Like the Lehigh University benchmark like SP2 bench.
But for this Federated setting so far, no dedicated benchmarks have been proposed.
So why do we think we we need dedicated benchmarks here?
Well, on the one hand we have these were radically different requirements, and this radically different set.

On the other hand, in this Federated query processing, we really have a large heterogeneity of use cases, which means, depending on what exactly you want to do in such a Federated context, you may have a couple of dimensions where the applications differ in in data and in query level.

So in data level you may be faced with local sources versus remote sort as you are faced when you're dealing with linked data with different kind of data access interfaces, you may have native repository.

Michael endpoints Link data hidden behind HTTP, then in particular, in this last case you may not even know what kind of data is out there, so you may need to do iterative loops to get information about what kind of data and what kind of information is out there for answering queries.
And finally from a query optimization perspective there is the issue of data statistics.
How much data statistics do you have in such a Federated setting for optimizing queries?
Do you have only few knowledge about the databases or do you have detailed information in form of histograms which you can use for query optimization?

And then again, on the other hand, on the query level, depending on which kind of application you write, you may have a factors like different or require different query language expressiveness and complexity.
You may be interested in complete results.
Other applications may be interested in only incomplete results for gaining some performance.
Then you may have ranking is use or other types of characteristics in these queries like different joint types.
Result seisan and so on and so forth.

So what we argue here is that there cannot be A1 size fits all benchmark for Federated query processing, but rather what we need is a flexible benchmarks you that can be customized according to the system to the use case that I want to benchmark.
And this was exactly the design goal that we had in mind when designing this FedEx benchmark.
So.
So how does FedEx look like?
So the first component of FedEx are datasets that are designed to be used in a Federated setting.
There were carefully choosing to varying aspects like decree of structured nest, domain size and have been grouped in several.
Action, so in total we have chosen three collections, where each collection contains a couple of datasets and when running the benchmarks we deploy one data set as one Federation member.
So in this cross domain setting here we have six datasets in total, so when running the benchmark we have six Federation over these six Members.
So what kind of data do we have there really different heterogeneous data from different domains?
In particular DB pedia.
As a central hub, then we have data from the media domain like Link, movie, Database and Jamendo.
We have two names with two information.
We have the semantic web dog food data and New York Times link data in this connection.
Then we have chosen a domain specific collection in the life Sciences, again containing DB pedia as a central hub, and ridged with information from track bank, KB and tech.

And finally, we have also chosen to include synthetic data generated from the SP2 bench data generator and this benchmark originally designed for centralized abroad with what we did here, we split this total data set into in total 16 packets according to the types that are appearing in these datasets.
So we get 16 packets of different size, which we could again diploid in effect.
Bration Dan.
These datasets are complemented by dedicated queries that operate under collection.
To start with a small example here we have a very simple query which lists all US presidents, including their party and associated news.
So this query is to be executed over the cross domain collection, but in the end only these two datasets will really contribute to the final result.
So we have one part of the query that is basically answered or gives answers when evaluated on DB pedia.

There we bind this president variable here and then we look up the corresponding urri for a president in the New York Times data set and find a topic page which contains additional information from New York Times through the respective president.
Of course, I'm not gonna to discuss all queries in detail, so maybe just a summary.
In the following we have four sets of queries.
First we have one query set in the life science domain containing 7 queries.
We have two query sets in the cross domain for the cross domain data collections, one queryset focusing on the full spark.
It's standard one query set which was.
Specifically designed to test link data processing, which means iterative.
Look up your eye loops when when these datasets are diploid, as linked data, and then we reuse the queries from the SP2 bench benchmark to be answered on the Federated SP2 bench data set.

So here are some statistics about the queries which showed any squares really vary in in different aspects, like which operators are used, which solution modifier used, what is the structure of the queries, how big is the result size, what is the number of resources of sources involved in answering the query.
So the first 2 lines are the operators and the solution Modifyers ACE stands for NU for Union.

Offer options fo filter so it's the standard sparkle operator set and then we have solution modifyers like order by distinct limit and offset and what we can see in total is that we really cover a broad range of solution modifyers year in combination with with with different operator constellations.
So we cover queries of different complexity negation queries.
Simple joint, very simple conjunctive queries, all the.
All the other bunch of crazy you might imagine.

A second important aspect is the number of sources that may be potentially involved in answering query, where by potentially involved I mean make contributor result to at least one triple pattern in the query.

So I see for the life science and cross domain queries we have typically 2 between five sources that contribute potentially contribute to the result, whereas for the SP2 bench this is much higher in complexity.
Then we also have much more sources, namely 16 in total, and they are in average, yeah between 11 and an 14 sources are involved in or could be involved in answering their queries.

So the datasets and queries are then finally complemented by a benchmark driver which was implemented in Java is available open source and can also be easily adjusted and extended to own experiments an which allows to execute the benchmark in a unified way.
The benchmark driver basis on the SESAME API.
So you can basically plug in every system that implements the generic sesame interfaces, and it allows you to be a simple config file, specify the data and the queries.
The number of runs timeouts that you want to use, and very importantly also the deployment method of the data.
So when loading the data, do you want to have these Federation members as native Repository's?
Do you want to have them set up as linked data or sparkle endpoints?
So all this the benchmark driver will be able to do for you and assist you in setting up your setting and executing the queries.
And as output driver rights then Alternatively CSV or RDF.
Trials and as an additional service.

We have implemented a small module for the Information Workbench which is a platform for wiki based interaction with link data so you can upload this RDF generated by the by the benchmark driver and then you will immediately get some statistic in form of tables in form of dashboards and charts.
Visualizing your benchmark results.
OK, so so far to the benchmark description.
In the remainder of the talk I will elaborate a little bit on the experiments that we did on our benchmark.

The goal of these experiments was basically to prove the predictability and flexibility of our benchmark, which means we wanted to show it with this benchmarks would we are really able to cover a broad variety of scenarios in this Federated link data processing context.
We wanted to assess the first state of the art engine.
And of course we wanted to show that we're really able to identify weaknesses and strengths of existing systems.
So what we did or what we measured were mostly query evaluation time.
Also, loading time of the datasets and number of requests that were sent to the remote sources.
I will present or elaborate on this later on and we decided to carry out the experiments in a local setting so.
We run everything on a single 32 gigabyte machine 32 gigabyte RAM machine locali becausw.
The problem is when you are really using external sparkle endpoints in the web, then you cannot guarantee that your experiments are actual repeatable.
You cannot guarantee that, well, these endpoints are free or used by other applications, so you cannot get really valuable results out of this.
So that's why we diploid all these.
Federation members locally on one machine and carried out the experiments against these.

The first scenario we tested was.
Intended to test how does a centralized storage centralized scenario behave compared to a Federated query processing scenario.

The first scenario titled A1 Here is centralized processing where we loaded these data collection into one central store, so no Federation at all and we evaluated the queries directly against these.
Central store, so we tested this with the Sesame 231 system.

The second scenario is titled local Federation, and here we use the Sesame Plus Alibaba which is a prominent Federation layer for Sesame and this is called local Federation because what we did here is we had a very a couple or we loaded the individual datasets into local sesame.
Repository's is so so everything was inside one system so we did not have separate bucket endpoints.
But really, a local repository is within Sesame, so the communication between the Federation layer and these Federation members was not over HTTP, but the system internally.

And then the third scenario and assert scenario we set up real sparkle endpoints for the Federation members, and again here we tested Sesame three to one and Alibaba, and in addition we tested the splendid system which was developed from West.
Also, one of the Co authors of the paper, all of Berlitz and here.
The idea was also to compare how this these two systems related to each other.

So in summary we said 10 minute timer per query and the following experiment will report on the average over three runs after a short warmup phase where we run some premixes against the back end to warm up caches.
So here are as one example, the results for the Life science query set on the Life Science data collection.

The total data size of the Federation was 50 million triples.

Then we have the local Federation.
The search bar is always the endpoint Federation with Ali Baba and the first part of the fourth prize.
The Endpoint Federation with suspended system.

The local Federation was added.
Excuse me, the centralized store was in almost all the experiments, most performant.
Or at least as or at most, as at least as performed as a local Federation.
Which indicates that that query optimization in such a centralized setting is quite hard and requires to take quite good care and new strategies.
As for the local Federation, in some cases it could still compete with the centralized approach, while in some cases it required still considerably more time.
Like for instance, as you can see here for this query it's about 3 orders of magnitude slower, so this is a log scale diagram.
And then again we have a gap between this local Federation and the Endpoint Federation which can be explained quite well by the overhead.
That is imposed by sending requests over HTTP, and this is a gap of typically one order of magnitude.
And it indicates that while minimizing the number of requests in such a setting is very crucial to optimizing queries.

And when comparing the Endpoint Federation of Ali Baba and the Endpoint Federation of Splendid, we see that splendid in many cases like here, here, here does a much better job and this can simply be explained by the table below which shows the number of requests that are sent during query evaluation.
Two Federation members and splendid here users avoid statistics about the data set which have been precomputed to minimize the number of.
Request to do.

Intelligence source selection and to do not send triple parents to sources where it a priority can say they will not give answers to these these queries and this directly manifests in better evaluation times in the.

So the second scenario we evaluated with quite a different one and the focus here was a link data query processing, so really linked data in the in the sense that we do not have sparkle endpoints here, but we do HTTP log apps to gather data and iteratively based on the data we found evaluated query find, knew your eyes and look up this your eyes again.
And in this scenario we tested.
Three approaches, a bottom up approach where we start with your eyes in the query that we resolve to get subgraphs and then iteratively well find new sources in the in the.
Web of data.
The second approach here was a top down approach where we use our priority knowledge about which data sources are there and 1st extract all the sources and then evaluate the query locally.
And then there's also a mixed approach which.
Users partially top down knowledge and also starts evaluating the query bottom up.
So it's basically a combination of the two former approaches.
The systems we tested here, where dedicated prototype implementations from two of the courses which represented in the last years I SWC I want to refer this position to the paper for more details.
The major findings here which we we could confirm with our benchmark was that for the top down approach in most cases is most performant which is also not surprising because.
There we already have a lot of information from the beginning.

We know which data sources are relevant, but the mixed approach was quite competitive with this and the benefit of using this mixed approach was that it typically yielded earlier results reporting so.
It took a little bit longer until we had the full result, but we got initial our first results very early with with this mixed approach, so it's a good alternative.
At least two to the top down approach.

So to summarize the experiment, what we have learned here is that in a in a Federated setting, an effective join ordering is often impossible when no intelligent source selection strategy is given, and we when we do not have statistics about data core data set, and in such cases this results often in a very high number of requests that are sent to the Federation members, which is caused by.
Iterative nested loop evaluation strategies of these Federated.
Implementations and another thing we observed is our limited capabilities of Sesame to deal with parallelization, which caused problems.

If we had in the individual sparkle endpoints, the two high number of working threads and two high number of incoming requests, then we often observed that Sesame became very, very slow because of probably internal locking issues and the following talk we will see a system called FedEx that tackles exactly this.
Questions so it builds up on the findings that we gathered within.
This benchmark.

The evaluation has revealed severe deficiencies of today's approaches.
